I'm always on the lookout for a salad that's fun and flavorful.Â ğŸ¥— Whether that's adding caramelized onions, creamy dressings, spiced nuts, or some punchy chopped fruit.Â While delicious, Caesar salads are drowned in dressing and covered with cheese.Â So Iâ€™ve partnered with @wholefoods in the spirit of the the New Year to show you #HowIJanuary and Iâ€™ve remixed this classic salad to help you enjoy it in a new and delicious way. I pared down your typical Caesar to still offer all that creamy goodness with a vegan dressing, some gluten-free croutons, and I swapped in shaved brussels sprouts because they're a good source of fiber and hold up in the fridge for a few days. Follow the link in my profile to find more gluten-free options for you to add to your meals!Â #Sponsored #MakesMeWhole

Here's the recipe below:

RECIPE:
Brussels Sprouts Caesar Salad: -2lbs. brussels sprouts, shaved thin on a mandolin or with a sharp knife
- drizzle extra virgin olive oil
- squeeze lemon juice
- fat pinch salt
-1 ripe avocado, sliced
- gluten-free croutons (optional)
- walnuts shaved on a microplane, to garnish (optional) 
Dressing: -1/2 c Plain Kite Hill Greek-style yogurt
-1 tablespoon lemon juice
-1 tablespoon apple cider vinegar
-1 1/2 tablespoons nutritional yeast
-2 teaspoons Dijon mustard
-2 teaspoons capers
-1 clove garlic, grated on a microplane
-Salt & pepper, to taste
-1/4 cup plus 2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil 
1. Toss shaved brussels sprouts with the olive oil, lemon juice, and salt. Â Use your hands and mix everything together for about 1 minute. Â Set aside.
2. Make the dressing. Â In a food processor fitted with a metal â€œsâ€ blade, combine the yogurt, lemon juice, vinegar, nutritional yeast, Dijon, capers, garlic, and salt and pepper to taste. Â With the machine running drizzle in the Â¼ cup of olive oil until everything is combined. Â Remove the lid and check the dressing, if itâ€™s too thick, add the extra 2 tablespoons of olive oil and combine once again. Â Taste and adjust salt if needed. 
3. To the shaved brussels sprouts, add roughly half the dressing and mix. Â Taste, and add more dressing and salt if needed. Â Top w/ sliced avocado, gf croutons & shaved walnuts

Regardless of the season, I always keep cookies on hand. Iâ€™ve teamed up with @wholefoods to show some of my favorite picks for the New Year and this recipe is one of my all-time go-to options. I particularly like having these almond butter cookies around â€“they're full of fats from almond butter, and they're made with monkfruit sweetener, which can replace added sugars. But they totally fill the 3-4pm void when I need a cookie! Get the recipe for these delicious babes below!  #Sponsored @wholefoods #HowIJanuary #MakesMeWhole
RECIPE:

Almond Butter Cookies: - 1 1/4 cups almond butter
- 1/2 cup monkfruit sweetener
- 1 large egg
- flaky sea salt, for topping 
1. Preheat oven to 350Â°F and line a cookie sheet with parchment paper.  Set aside.
2. In a large bowl, mix together the almond butter, sweetener, and egg until thoroughly combined. 
3. Using a cookie scoop, or by hand, portion the cookie dough into 1 Â½ tablespoon balls and place them on your cookie sheet leaving about an inch between each cookie.  Using a fork, gently press the cookies cookies down making an imprint. 
4. Bake the cookies for 12-14 minutes.  Let cool completely before eating. ğŸªğŸªğŸª

New favorite tea paired with my new favorite milk: @sakaralife detox tea (which Iâ€™ve been loving to drink each afternoon), and a vanilla, coconut, cashew blend of homemade milk thatâ€™s been hitting the spot lately. 
The tea has rooibos, lemongrass, and rose which is so good on its own. But that little hit of creamy coconut-y milk takes it up a teeny notch. 
Hereâ€™s a rough sketch of a recipe for the milk:
â€¢ 1/2 cup raw cashews (soaked 3 hrs)

â€¢ 3 cups filtered water

Getting back to the basics with my typical grocery #wholefoodshaul for about 3-4 days.Â Iâ€™m teaming up with @wholefoods to show you my favorite staples for the new year. 
Buying all of our groceries and prepping for an entire week has never worked for us. Instead I buy groceries for 3-4 days.Â  Our schedules inevitably shift and change depending on the week, so this little system actually saves us money and our food never goes bad.
